query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
1 Quando per dilettanze o ver per doglie, 2 che alcuna virtù nostra comprenda, 3 l’anima bene ad essa si raccoglie,
4 par ch’a nulla potenza più intenda; 5 e questo è contra quello error che crede 6 ch’un’anima sovr’ altra in noi s’accenda.
query.result:
**English:**
1 When, for pleasure or for pain, 2 some power of ours is engaged, 3 the soul gathers itself closely to it,
4 and seems to pay attention to nothing else; 5 and this is against the mistaken belief 6 that one soul can be kindled within us over another.
**Cornish:**
1 Pythegyn po leasow po rag dolgow, 2 pan vo gwellheans agan gavas, 3 an eneval a wra dhe'y hy honan,
4 ytholl nag esa gallos moy es dhe bys; 5 ha henna yw yn-erbyn an golladh na 6 yth esa eneval arall ow kul yn-agan.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
13 Di ciò ebb’ io esperïenza vera, 14 udendo quello spirto e ammirando; 15 ché ben cinquanta gradi salito era
16 lo sole, e io non m’era accorto, quando 17 venimmo ove quell’ anime ad una 18 gridaro a noi: «Qui è vostro dimando».
query.result:
**English:**
13 Of this I had true experience, 14 hearing that spirit and marvelling; 15 for the sun had already climbed fifty degrees,
16 and I had not noticed it, when 17 we came to where those souls together 18 cried out to us: "Here is what you asked for."
**Cornish:**
13 A-dro dhe henna yth esa genen gwir, 14 ow klevos an sperys na ha owth omladhya; 15 rag an howl o seth degres o sevel o,
16 ha'n va kovsens, pan dheuthsya 17 dhe'n le mayth an enevelow na dhe-ugh 18 ow klewas dhe'n: "Yma an peth a with."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
19 Maggiore aperta molte volte impruna 20 con una forcatella di sue spine 21 l’uom de la villa quando l’uva imbruna,
22 che non era la calla onde salìne 23 lo duca mio, e io appresso, soli, 24 come da noi la schiera si partìne.
query.result:
**English:**
19 A villager often makes a larger opening 20 with a small pitchfork of his thorns 21 when the grapes turn brown,
22 than was the path by which my leader climbed, 23 and I after him, alone, 24 when the troop departed from us.
**Cornish:**
19 Moy es ytholl dhe'n den a'n drehev 20 gans forkel byghan a'y spynnow, 21 pan wra an uvas ow tyrra,
22 ages an fordh mayth yth esa'n dewis 23 an dew a'm sevel, ha my a-wosa, onan, 24 pan dheuth an skoodh a-barth anow.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
31 Noi salavam per entro ’l sasso rotto, 32 e d’ogne lato ne stringea lo stremo, 33 e piedi e man volea il suol di sotto.
query.result:
**English:**
31 We climbed through the broken rock, 32 and on each side the narrow pass constricted us, 33 and the ground below demanded hands and feet.
**Cornish:**
31 Ny a sevel trwy'n garrek torrys, 32 ha dhe pub tu dhe'n fordh kul a'n golwas, 33 ha'n leur ha'n dorn a vynnas an leur a-woles.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
34 Poi che noi fummo in su l’orlo suppremo 35 de l’alta ripa, a la scoperta piaggia, 36 «Maestro mio», diss’ io, «che via faremo?».
query.result:
**English:**
34 After we were on the topmost edge 35 of the high cliff, on the open hillside, 36 "My master," I said, "what path shall we take?"
**Cornish:**
34 Wosa ny veu dhe'n ughella ughella 35 a'n garrek ughel, dhe'n fordh apert, 36 "An mester," me a leveris, "pyth fordh a wra ny?"

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
37 Ed elli a me: «Nessun tuo passo caggia; 38 pur su al monte dietro a me acquista, 39 fin che n’appaia alcuna scorta saggia».
query.result:
**English:**
37 And he to me: "Let not your step falter; 38 just keep climbing the mountain behind me, 39 until some wise guide appears to us."
**Cornish:**
37 Ha henna dhe'm leveris: "Na wra dhe'n gamm dhe dhrehedha; 38 mes pur dhe'n menydh wosa'm, 39 bys mayth dhe weler ny skoodh fur a'n gweles."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
40 Lo sommo er’ alto che vincea la vista, 41 e la costa superba più assai 42 che da mezzo quadrante a centro lista.
query.result:
**English:**
40 The summit was so high that it surpassed the sight, 41 and the proud slope was much steeper 42 than the arc from the middle to the center of a quadrant.
**Cornish:**
40 An ughella o sevel o fethas an golwg, 41 ha'n fordh baldh o sevel moy es ughella 42 ages han kwadrans a-ves dhe'n kres.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
43 Io era lasso, quando cominciai: 44 «O dolce padre, volgiti, e rimira 45 com’ io rimango sol, se non restai».
query.result:
**English:**
43 I was weary when I began: 44 "O gentle father, turn and look, 45 how I remain alone, if you do not stay."
**Cornish:**
43 Yth oen fethys, pan dhallathas: 44 "O tas dhe, tro ha gwel, 45 pyth vyth vyth onan, mar ny wodh hedhas."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
46 «Figliuol mio», disse, «infin quivi ti tira», 47 additandomi un balzo poco in sùe 48 che da quel lato il poggio tutto gira.
query.result:
**English:**
46 "My son," he said, "pull yourself up to here," 47 pointing out to me a ledge a little higher up 48 that goes all around the hill on that side.
**Cornish:**
46 "Va mab," ev a leveris, "hedre vyth hedhas," 47 ow tiskwedhes vyth bal rag dhe'n ughella, 48 ow tos owrth an bre dhe'n tu gwra.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
49 Sì mi spronaron le parole sue, 50 ch’i’ mi sforzai carpando appresso lui, 51 tanto che ’l cinghio sotto i piè mi fue.
query.result:
**English:**
49 His words so spurred me on, 50 that I made an effort, climbing after him, 51 until the ledge was beneath my feet.
**Cornish:**
49 Ytho geiriow ef a spronyas vyth, 50 owth ow tos ow sparra ow holya orth, 51 bys dhe'n cing ow tos ow'm troos vyth tres.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
52 A seder ci ponemmo ivi ambedui 53 vòlti a levante ond’ eravam saliti, 54 che suole a riguardar giovare altrui.
query.result:
**English:**
52 We sat down there, both of us, 53 facing east, from where we had climbed, 54 which is usually good for people to look at.
**Cornish:**
52 Nyns esa ni dhe'n sedhes, an dhew, 53 ow tos ow holya dhe'n est, ow tos ow tos, 54 ow tos ow holya dhe'n dus ow tos dhe'n dus.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
55 Li occhi prima drizzai ai bassi liti; 56 poscia li alzai al sole, e ammirava 57 che da sinistra n’eravam feriti.
query.result:
**English:**
55 First I turned my eyes to the low shores; 56 then I raised them to the sun, and saw with wonder 57 that we were smitten by it from the left.
**Cornish:**
55 Kynsa'm drehevis om lagha'n glannow; 56 wosa henna'm a's kodhas orth an howl, ha gwelis 57 genesen ni a veu gwaynys gans an howl a'gan kleves.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
58 Ben s’avvide il poeta ch’ïo stava 59 stupido tutto al carro de la luce, 60 ove tra noi e Aquilone intrava.
query.result:
**English:**
58 The poet realized that I was standing 59 completely stunned at the chariot of the sun, 60 where it was entering between us and the North Wind.
**Cornish:**
58 Mes ev a welas an bardh genesen ow talleth 59 marow marow orth karros an howl, 60 le mayth genesen ni ha Gwythvos ow mos a'gan mysk.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
61 Ond’ elli a me: «Se Castore e Poluce 62 fossero in compagnia di quello specchio 63 che sù e giù del suo lume conduce,
64 tu vedresti il Zodïaco rubecchio 65 ancora a l’Orse più stretto rotare, 66 se non uscisse fuor del cammin vecchio.
query.result:
**English:**
61 And he said to me: "If Castor and Pollux 62 were in the company of that mirror 63 which guides its light up and down,
64 you would see the red Zodiac 65 still turning more tightly around the Bears, 66 if it did not stray from its old path.
**Cornish:**
61 Ha henna a leveris dhym: "Marow Kastor ha Poluks 62 a veu yn kummyas gans henna'n spekul 63 a ledyth y howl dhe-ha-dheworth,
64 ty a welo an Zodyak rudh 65 ow kul gwell orth an Arthow ow treylyas, 66 mar ny veu ev ow tos dhyworth y fordh koth."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
67 Come ciò sia, se ’l vuoi poter pensare, 68 dentro raccolto, imagina Sïòn 69 con questo monte in su la terra stare
70 sì, ch’amendue hanno un solo orizzòn 71 e diversi emisperi; onde la strada 72 che mal non seppe carreggiar Fetòn,
73 vedrai come a costui convien che vada 74 da l’un, quando a colui da l’altro fianco, 75 se lo ’ntelletto tuo ben chiaro bada».
query.result:
**English:**
67 How this may be, if you wish to be able to understand it, 68 imagine Sion gathered within itself, 69 with this mountain standing on the earth
70 so that both have a single horizon 71 and different hemispheres; thus you will see the road 72 that Phaethon did not know how to drive properly,
73 how it is necessary for this one to go 74 from the one side when the other goes from the other side, 75 if your intellect pays close attention.
**Cornish:**
67 Fatel mayth henna, mar karas powes y weles, 68 ow tos a-ves, meurysi Sïòn 69 gans an meneth ma orth an norvys.
70 Marow, an dhew a wra y'gan onan horizòn 71 ha emysferow dyffrans; orth henna ty a welo an fordh 72 na wodhas Phaethon y gwaynya yn isella,
73 fatel mayth henna yw rekis dhe vos 74 dhyworth an onan tu, pan vo an aral tu dhyworth an aral tu, 75 mar ow pewas orth an intelleks dhe yn kler.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
76 «Certo, maestro mio,» diss’ io, «unquanco 77 non vid’ io chiaro sì com’ io discerno 78 là dove mio ingegno parea manco,
79 che ’l mezzo cerchio del moto superno, 80 che si chiama Equatore in alcun’ arte, 81 e che sempre riman tra ’l sole e ’l verno,
82 per la ragion che di’, quinci si parte 83 verso settentrïon, quanto li Ebrei 84 vedevan lui verso la calda parte.
query.result:
**English:**
76 "Certainly, my master," I said, "never 77 have I seen so clearly as I now discern 78 where my intellect seemed lacking,
79 that the middle circle of the supernal motion, 80 which is called the Equator in some arts, 81 and which always remains between the sun and winter,
82 for the reason that you say, departs from here 83 towards the north, as much as the Hebrews 84 saw it towards the warm region.
**Cornish:**
76 "Yn wir, myghtern," me a leveris, "nagos vyth 77 ny wodhis vyth kler mar a welaf vyth 78 le mayth ow tressa ow intelleks ow tos mank,
79 genesen an hanter-kelgh an movyans ughella, 80 a veu gelwys an Ekwater yn nebes an artow, 81 ha a wra pub vyth ynter an howl ha'n gwav,
82 rag an reson a leveris, ow tos ow parti 83 orth an north, marow an Ebreow 84 a's gwelas orth an tu tomm."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
85 Ma se a te piace, volontier saprei 86 quanto avemo ad andar; ché ’l poggio sale 87 più che salir non posson li occhi miei».
query.result:
**English:**
85 But if it pleases you, I would gladly know 86 how much further we have to go; for the hill rises 87 more than my eyes can climb.
**Cornish:**
85 Mes mar karas dhis, ow karas gans wolonter gwybos 86 pyth a wra genesen dhymmyn dhe vos; rag an bre gwra 87 moy ages y'm lagha'm ow sevel."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
88 Ed elli a me: «Questa montagna è tale, 89 che sempre al cominciar di sotto è grave; 90 e quant’ om più va sù, e men fa male.
query.result:
**English:**
88 And he said to me: "This mountain is such 89 that it is always difficult to begin climbing it; 90 but the higher one goes, the less difficult it becomes.
**Cornish:**
88 Ha henna a leveris dhym: "An meneth ma yw marow, 89 genesen pub prys hyns orth an komensa yw krev; 90 ha ages moy a wra orth, moy a wra dalleth."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
91 Però, quand’ ella ti parrà soave 92 tanto, che sù andar ti fia leggero 93 com’ a seconda giù andar per nave,
94 allor sarai al fin d’esto sentiero; 95 quivi di riposar l’affanno aspetta.
query.result:
**English:**
91 Therefore, when it seems so pleasant to you 92 that going up will be as easy for you 93 as going down a river in a boat,
94 then you will be at the end of this path; 95 there you can expect to rest from your toil.
**Cornish:**
91 Rag henna, pan vo henna ow tos dhis marow 92 tomm, genesen orth dhe vos a wra gans es 93 marow orth avon dhe-ha-dheworth orth lestr,
94 henna yw bos dhe'n fordh ma; 95 le mayth ty a wra ow tos dhe vos dhe vos dhe'n boes.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
96 Più non rispondo, e questo so per vero».
97 E com’ elli ebbe sua parola detta, 98 una voce di presso sonò: «Forse 99 che di sedere in pria avrai distretta!».
query.result:
**English:**
96 I answer no more, and this I know for true."
97 And when he had spoken his word, 98 a voice from nearby sounded: "Perhaps 99 you will be forced to sit down first!"
**Cornish:**
96 Nyns ywth owth yskynna, ha henna a wythvos vyth.
97 Ha pan wrug efan leverel y ger, 98 un lef a-ugh a sonas: "Mar pleg, 99 y fydh dhethvos dhe sesa kyns!"

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
100 Al suon di lei ciascun di noi si torse, 101 e vedemmo a mancina un gran petrone, 102 del qual né io né ei prima s’accorse.
query.result:
**English:**
100 At the sound of it, each of us turned, 101 and on our left we saw a large boulder, 102 which neither I nor he had noticed before.
**Cornish:**
100 Orth y lef ev, pub onen a droas, 101 ha'n welas niver un men tol, 102 na vy nag ef na ef a-ragas kyns.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
103 Là ci traemmo; e ivi eran persone 104 che si stavano a l’ombra dietro al sasso 105 come l’uom per negghienza a star si pone.
query.result:
**English:**
103 We went there; and there were people 104 who were standing in the shade behind the boulder, 105 as a man sits down out of laziness.
**Cornish:**
103 Rys ni a-dro, ha eno o tusow 104 ow sevel orth y skedh a-dhelergh an men, 105 kepar ha'n den a-sesa orth rag les.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
106 E un di lor, che mi sembiava lasso, 107 sedeva e abbracciava le ginocchia, 108 tenendo ’l viso giù tra esse basso.
query.result:
**English:**
106 And one of them, who seemed weary to me, 107 was sitting and embracing his knees, 108 keeping his face down low between them.
**Cornish:**
106 Ha unn orth aga, ow a welas marthys, 107 o sevel ha'y gludhes orth y lin, 108 ow kregi y edhen isel orth aga.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
109 «O dolce segnor mio», diss’ io, «adocchia 110 colui che mostra sé più negligente 111 che se pigrizia fosse sua serocchia».
query.result:
**English:**
109 "O my sweet lord," I said, "look at 110 the one who shows himself to be more indolent 111 than if laziness were his sister."
**Cornish:**
109 "O fy arglu melyon," me a leveris, 110 "sel an neb a wragh y honan moyha 111 ages o ve pilgreth o ve serch."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
112 Allor si volse a noi e puose mente, 113 movendo ’l viso pur su per la coscia, 114 e disse: «Or va tu sù, che se’ valente!».
query.result:
**English:**
112 Then he turned to us and paid attention, 113 moving his face up along his thigh, 114 and said: "Now go up, for you are strong!"
**Cornish:**
112 Pan droas ef a-ugh ni ha'y skila, 113 ow treylya y edhen orth y lin, 114 ha leverel: "Ker, mos dhe-ugh, rag es gallus!"

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
115 Conobbi allor chi era, e quella angoscia 116 che m’avacciava un poco ancor la lena, 117 non m’impedì l’andare a lui; e poscia
118 ch’a lui fu’ giunto, alzò la testa a pena, 119 dicendo: «Hai ben veduto come ’l sole 120 da l’omero sinistro il carro mena?».
query.result:
**English:**
115 Then I knew who he was, and that anguish 116 which was still weighing down my breath a little, 117 did not prevent me from going to him; and afterwards
118 when I had reached him, he barely raised his head, 119 saying: "You have seen well how the sun 120 drives his chariot from the left shoulder?"
**Cornish:**
115 Me a-wodha pan pyw ef, ha'n angos 116 ow a-wruk vy un lyha byw y enef, 117 ny wrug ef lettya vy dhe mos dhe-ugh; ha wosa
118 pan o veas dhe-ugh, ef a-hedhas y ben, 119 ow leverel: "Es gwelas vy pyw an howl 120 ow treylya y gerri a-ugh y skwith kleth?"

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
121 Li atti suoi pigri e le corte parole 122 mosser le labbra mie un poco a riso; 123 poi cominciai: «Belacqua, a me non dole
124 di te omai; ma dimmi: perché assiso 125 quiritto se’? attendi tu iscorta, 126 o pur lo modo usato t’ha’ ripriso?».
query.result:
**English:**
121 His lazy actions and curt words 122 moved my lips to a slight smile; 123 then I began: "Belacqua, I am not sorry
124 for you now; but tell me: why are you sitting 125 here? Are you waiting for an escort, 126 or has your old habit taken hold of you again?"
**Cornish:**
121 Y oberow pilgreth ha'y gerrow berr 122 a wrug vy owth gweles dhe wraga, 123 pan a-leveris: "Belacqua, nyns ywth gorra
124 rag dheth; mes lever vy: rag wragh es sevel 125 ama? Es gorth yskorta, 126 po an dhodh koth a-dhemedh dhe-ugh?"

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
127 Ed elli: «O frate, andar in sù che porta? 128 ché non mi lascerebbe ire a’ martìri 129 l’angel di Dio che siede in su la porta.
query.result:
**English:**
127 And he: "O brother, what good does it do to go up? 128 For the angel of God who sits at the gate 129 would not let me go to purgatory.
**Cornish:**
127 Ha ef: "O froder, pyw ywth mos dhe-ugh mos dhe-ugh? 128 Rag ny wrug ef lettya vy dhe mos dhe-ugh dhe'n vortiryon 129 an el a Dhew ow sydh orth an porth.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
130 Prima convien che tanto il ciel m’aggiri 131 di fuor da essa, quanto fece in vita, 132 per ch’io ’ndugiai al fine i buon sospiri,
133 se orazïone in prima non m’aita 134 che surga sù di cuor che in grazia viva; 135 l’altra che val, che ’n ciel non è udita?».
query.result:
**English:**
130 First, I must wander outside it for as long 131 as I did in life, 132 because I delayed my good sighs until the end,
133 unless a prayer helps me first 134 to rise up from the heart that lives in grace; 135 what good is the other kind, which is not heard in heaven?"
**Cornish:**
130 Kyns, rag wra dhe-ugh treylya a-ugh an nef 131 a-ves orth aga, kepar ha wrug ef ober 132 rag wrug vy oji dhe'n fin y syghys da,
133 mar nyns yw gwedhi vy kyns ow skoedha 134 dhe hedhes dhe-ugh a-ugh colon ow triga yn gras; 135 pyw ywth mos an aral, ow nyns yw klevys yn nef?"

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
136 E già il poeta innanzi mi saliva, 137 e dicea: «Vienne omai; vedi ch’è tocco 138 meridïan dal sole e a la riva
139 cuopre la notte già col piè Morrocco».
query.result:
**English:**
136 And now the poet was climbing ahead of me, 137 and he said: "Come now; see that midday has been touched 138 by the sun and night is already covering Morocco with its foot 139 at the shore".
**Cornish:**
136 Ha menowgh an bardh a-rag dhe'm, 137 ha leverel: "Dosomeur; gweles pan vo dheuth 138 an hanterdydh gans an howl ha'n nos 139 a wra kovra Morrocco gans y troos war an arvor".
